subject: Re: [junit] using JUnit with derived classes
msgSnippet: ... Put simply, what you propose to do goes entirely against JUnit s philosophy, as well as the more general testing philosophies of the xUnit family of
messageBody:
Glenn Robitaille wrote:

>
> I've read tons of documentation & hype on JUnit, and how it is the
> de facto unit test tool for Java. While I agree with a lot of the
> JUnit philosophy, I have one major concern with it. Perhaps there
> are articles out there that address this, but I can't find any of
> them.
>
> As I look into JUnit, it seems that each class either has to do one
> of the following:
>
> extend TestCase
> implement Test.
> extend some other class that implements Test.
>
> As we all know, Java doesn't support multiple inheritance. You can
> only extend TestCase or you business class, but not both. If you
> want to use JUnit with a derived class, it seems you have to
> implement a lot of methods from the TestCase interface -- which
> isn't practical.
>
> What are some of the ways people use JUnit to test classes that are
> derived classes? Are there splinter projects that address this
> deficiency? Or is JUnit a poor fit for derived classes?

Put simply, what you propose to do goes entirely against JUnit's
philosophy, as well as the more general testing philosophies of the
xUnit family of testing frameworks. Tests are tests and production code
is production code.

Why do you want a production class also to be a test? I think it's
generally a very bad idea.

This brings up something I am struggling with: in C#/NUnit, we can
declare a test without extending TestCase (even if we frequently extend
Assert, anyway). Is there some great benefit to this over the way we do
it in JUnit, SUnit, RubyUnit, PyUnit, ...?
